ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
My Calc 2 knowledge has greatly improved by taking this class. I went in with AB Calc knowledge, which was a great foundation and I think the placement test put me in exactly the right place. 
I also realized how I learn best, which is to take advantage of study resources that Yale provides.
In this class, I learned about single variable integrals, parametric equations, as well as series/sequences as a tool for representing functions.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think there is a very noticeable, and inequitable disparity between the teachers that are in this course. There is a very large difference between someone who takes a class with the department head who not only writes the exams but also speaks clearly and can explain material well, and someone who takes a class with someone with an extremely thick accent and not the best way to explain content. This is not to say that people with thick accents cannot teach, only that if you take both these students at face value, one will stand out more than the other.

Strengths: This course promotes collaborative work. Problem Sets and in lecture exercises are often collaborative, and during office hours, we are encouraged to work in large groups before we consult the TA's about problems we are stuck on. I think this is useful because we have a variety of ways to improve and learn. 

Weaknesses: Considering how often we complete problem sets, I think it is a weakness of this class that they are worth so little. It is our main way to practice the concepts we learn in class. Problem Sets can be a major reflection of growth, whereas exams are one shot, and we only get 3. Additionally, another weakness I found was that problem sets often go a while before they are graded, making it a little difficult to track your progress.
The class time was very short, i think students might benefit from longer or more frequent meetings.
Way too difficult problem sets that sometimes require you to learn the material yourself, the explorations were stressful rather than helpful. Review sessions were excellent.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I think if you have to take it as a prereq, do it. It's 100% doable and survivable but I wouldn't do it for fun.

Yes this class promotes a mastery of derivatives and antiderivatives, which I found necessary for classes like econ. Additionally, so many people take this class that you're likely to know a friend or two who are in it. The collaborative aspect of this course makes learning enjoyable for an otherwise challenging class.
Yes, in many cases the class is required so a student must take it but even for the sake of a QR credit the class was pleasant and not too challenging.

I found it incredibly interesting, but if you are not invested in math and would take the course simply as a prerequisite, I wouldn't recommend it. It's up to the individual, but the course itself is worth it
